question: Who is required to report under subpart W?
answer: The facilities required to report under subpart W include onshore petroleum and natural gas production facilities, onshore petroleum and natural gas gathering and boosting facilities, underground natural gas storage facilities, LNG import and export facilities, LNG storage facilities, and onshore natural gas processing facilities. The document also mentions the use of best engineering estimates for data collection in the first 6 months for newly acquired sources and special provisions for reporting under subpart W for certain facilities. Additionally, the provided text contains tables with emission factors for different components and equipment in onshore petroleum and natural gas production, gathering, boosting, and processing facilities, as well as for underground natural gas storage. These tables provide specific emission factors for different regions and types of equipment, which can be used for calculating emissions from these facilities. The emission factors are provided for different survey methods, such as those specified in § 98.234(a)(1) through (6) and Method 21 as specified in § 98.234(a)(7). The emission factors are given in units of scf/hour/component and can be used to estimate emissions from the mentioned facilities.
truth: This rule making requires reporting from the following petroleum and natural gas industry segments: onshore petroleum and natural gas production, offshore petroleum and natural gas production, onshore natural gas processing, natural gas transmission compression, underground natural gas storage, liquefied natural gas (LNG) storage and LNG import and export.  Facilities that contain petroleum and natural gas systems that emit 25,000 metric tons or more of CO2 equivalent per year are required to report annual GHG emissions to EPA.

question: What GHG emissions at oil and natural gas system facilities are covered under the rule?
answer: The document provides detailed information about the types of GHG emissions at oil and natural gas system facilities that are covered under the rule. It outlines the equipment and operations included in these facilities, such as gathering pipelines, compressors, dehydrators, storage vessels, engines, boilers, heaters, and flares. Additionally, it specifies the reporting requirements for GHG emissions from these facilities, including the types of emissions to be reported and the calculation methods to be used. The document also emphasizes the importance of common ownership or control in defining a facility and provides specific thresholds for reporting emissions from different industry segments. Furthermore, it includes various equations and conversion factors for calculating emissions, such as the conversion factor for lb/dscf-ppm N2O, ratio of molecular weights, conversion factors for tons to metric tons, and unit conversion factors. The document also includes tables with emission factors for different components and equipment in onshore petroleum and natural gas production, gathering, and boosting facilities, as well as default average component counts for major equipment. Overall, it offers a comprehensive overview of the GHG emissions covered under the rule and the methods for calculating and reporting these emissions.
truth: Subpart W of part 98 requires petroleum and natural gas facilities to report annual methane (CH4) and carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions from equipment leaks and venting, and emissions of CO2, CH4, and nitrous oxide (N2O) from flaring, onshore production stationary and portable combustion emissions, and combustion emissions from stationary equipment involved in natural gas distribution. Facilities covered by this rule might also be required to report emissions under other subparts of the GHG Reporting Program, if applicable.  The GHG Reporting Program requires reporting of GHG emissions: CO2, CH4, nitrous oxide (N2O), and fluorinated GHGs: hydrofluorocarbons (HFC), perfluorocarbons (PFC), nitrogen trifluoride (NF3), sulfur hexafluoride (SF6), and other fluorinated gases.  These gases are often expressed in metric tons of carbon dioxide equivalent (mtCO2e).

question: Will EPA provide a tool to assist oil and natural gas system facilities in assessing their applicability under this rule?
answer: The document provides detailed definitions and criteria for onshore petroleum and natural gas production, gathering and boosting, natural gas processing, and transmission compression. It outlines the requirements for reporting emissions from various equipment and facilities, including the calculation methods and emission factors to be used. However, it does not explicitly mention whether the EPA will provide a specific tool to assist oil and natural gas system facilities in assessing their applicability under this rule. The document also includes several equations and tables related to emission factors, population emission factors, and default average component counts for major onshore natural gas production equipment, which can be used to calculate emissions and assess applicability under the rule.

truth: EPA has developed a voluntary screening tool for the petroleum and natural gas source category to assist reporters in their applicability determinations - the "applicability tool".  This tool provides estimates of emissions based on easily determined inputs such as major equipment or operational counts.  While the applicability tool is designed to help potential reporters comply with the rule, compliance with all Federal, State, and local laws and regulations remains the sole responsibility of each facility owner or operator subject to those laws and regulations. The applicability tool only serves as a guide to determine those facilities that are clearly well below the reporting threshold, those clearly above, and those close to the threshold who will need to collect further data to make a proper determination.

question: Do the facility definitions in this rule affect other EPA reporting requirements?
answer: The document provides comprehensive information about the reporting requirements and exemptions related to SF6 and PFC emissions at the facility level. It outlines the conditions under which facilities are required to report, including specific subparts and emission thresholds. It also specifies the exemptions, such as when the total nameplate capacity of SF6 and PFC containing equipment does not exceed 17,820 pounds. Additionally, the document includes details about the use of best available monitoring methods and the submission of one-time reports for specific products. The provided equations and tables offer detailed information on emission factors, component counts, and population emission factors for various equipment and processes, which are essential for understanding and complying with the reporting requirements. Overall, the document addresses the impact of facility definitions on other EPA reporting requirements by providing specific guidance and criteria for reporting SF6 and PFC emissions at the facility level.
truth: No. The definitions of “facility” in this rule do not impact requirements under other EPA regulations.

question: When registering my subpart W facility in e-GGRT, how should I enter the facility address?
answer: When registering a subpart W facility in e-GGRT, the facility address should include all physical properties, plants, buildings, structures, sources, or stationary equipment located on one or more contiguous or adjacent properties under common ownership or control that emit or may emit any greenhouse gas. Additionally, specific requirements for different types of facilities such as petrochemical plants, refineries, natural gas production facilities, and others are mentioned in the regulations. The document also provides various equations and tables related to emission factors, calibration errors, high heat values, and component counts for different types of facilities. These equations and tables are used to calculate and report emissions as per the regulations.
truth: The petroleum and natural gas systems source category (subpart W) of the Greenhouse Gas Reporting Program (GHGRP) covers 10 industry segments.  Four of these ten industry segments have a unique definition of facility that is specifically defined in subpart W, namely the onshore petroleum and natural gas production industry segment, the natural gas distribution industry segment, the onshore petroleum and natural gas gathering and boosting industry segment, and the onshore natural gas transmission pipeline industry segment.  Please follow the following guidance for registering and entering the facility address in e-GGRT:

question: How is the petroleum and natural gas systems source category defined?
answer: The petroleum and natural gas systems source category is defined as including onshore petroleum and natural gas production, onshore petroleum and natural gas gathering and boosting, onshore natural gas processing, and offshore petroleum and natural gas production. It encompasses equipment used in the production, extraction, recovery, lifting, stabilization, separation, or treating of petroleum and/or natural gas, as well as related storage and measurement vessels. The category also includes natural gas processing plants, natural gas transmission compression, underground natural gas storage, LNG storage, and LNG import and export equipment. It involves reporting of emissions from various equipment types, such as compressors, generators, dehydrators, storage vessels, engines, boilers, heaters, flares, and pneumatic devices/pumps. The emissions data for this source category must be quality assured and reported in accordance with specified monitoring and QA/QC requirements. Additionally, the category involves the calculation and reporting of GHG emissions from stationary or portable fuel combustion equipment. The document also outlines the reporting requirements for natural gas driven pneumatic pump venting, natural gas distribution, and natural gas processing plants. It provides definitions for terms such as natural gas liquids (NGLs), bulk NGLs, natural gasoline, and fossil fuel. The category also includes requirements for reporting the annual quantity of hydrocarbon liquids transported to various facilities, as well as the annual volumes of natural gas received for processing and bypassed the city gate(s). The document also provides various equations and tables for calculating emission factors, population emission factors, leaker emission factors, and other relevant data for different components and equipment in the petroleum and natural gas systems source category.

The category also includes natural gas processing plants, natural gas transmission compression, underground natural gas storage, LNG storage, and LNG import and export equipment. It involves reporting of emissions from various equipment types, such as compressors, generators, dehydrators, storage vessels, engines, boilers, heaters, flares, and pneumatic devices/pumps. question: Who must report under subpart W (oil and natural gas systems)?
answer: Onshore petroleum and natural gas production facilities and onshore petroleum and natural gas gathering and boosting facilities must report the information specified in paragraphs (r)(3)(ii)(A) and (B) of this section, for each major equipment type, production type (i.e., natural gas or crude oil), and geographic location combination in Tables W–1B and W–1C to this subpart for which equipment leak emissions are calculated using the methodology in § 98.233(r). The terms Owner and Operator used in subpart A have the same definition as Onshore petroleum and natural gas production owner or operator, as defined in § 98.238 of this part. Facilities required to report under onshore petroleum and natural gas production under subpart W of this part must report the information specified in paragraphs (r)(1)(i) through (v) separately by component type, service type, and geographic location (i.e., Eastern U.S. or Western U.S.). The document mentioned several calculation methods which explain how to derive the emission from the data. The equation describes E = COUNT * EF, where E represents the annual emissions, COUNT is the number of units, and EF is the emission factor. The emission factors for different components and services in the Eastern and Western U.S. for onshore petroleum and natural gas production and gathering facilities are provided in the tables. The tables also provide the average component counts for major equipment in the Eastern and Western U.S. for onshore natural gas production and gathering equipment, as well as for major crude oil production equipment. Additionally, there is a table that provides the designation of states into Eastern and Western U.S., which is relevant for reporting the information specified in paragraphs (r)(1)(i) through (v) separately by geographic location.
truth: Facilities that emit 25,000 metric tons or more of CO2e per year must report. The rule defines three different types of facilities. You must apply the 25,000 ton per year threshold separately to each facility to determine if that facility must report. • For the onshore petroleum and natural gas production industry segment, a facility is defined generally as all emission source types (see the table below) on a well pad or associated with a well pad that are under common ownership or control in a single hydrocarbon basin, as defined by the American Association of Petroleum Geologists. • For natural gas distribution industry segment, a facility generally is defined as the collection of all pipelines, metering stations, and regulating stations that are operated by a single local distribution company. • For all other industry segments, use the facility definition in the General Provisions to part 98. Under this definition, a facility is defined generally as all sources for which emission calculation methods are provided in 40 CFR part 98 (including those in the table below) and that are located on a contiguous property and under common ownership or common control. See 40 CFR part 98, subparts A and W for the precise definition of each of the three “facility” types.

question: What gases must be reported by oil and natural gas system facilities?
answer: Oil and natural gas system facilities must report CO2, CH4, and N2O emissions. The emissions are reported from equipment leaks, vented emissions, and flare emissions as identified in the data collection and emissions estimation study conducted by BOEMRE in compliance with 30 CFR 250.302 through 304. The provided input also contains a set of equations and tables related to emission factors, conversion factors, and population emission factors for different components and services in onshore petroleum and natural gas production and gathering. The tables provide detailed emission factors for various components such as valves, connectors, open-ended lines, pressure relief valves, and pumps, categorized by different services and material types. These factors are essential for estimating the emissions of CO2, CH4, and N2O from the mentioned facilities.
truth: Summary of Source Types by Industry Segment.  Each facility must report:• Carbon Dioxide (CO2) and methane (CH4) emissions from equipment leaks and vented emissions.  The table below identifies each source type that industry segments are required to report.  For example, natural gas processing facilities must report emissions from seven specific source types, and underground storage must report for five source types.• CO2, CH4, and nitrous oxide (N2O) emissions from gas flares by following the requirements of subpart W.• CO2, CH4, and N2O emissions from stationary and portable fuel combustion sources in the onshore production industry segment following the requirements in subpart W.• CO2, CH4, and N2O emissions from stationary combustion sources in the natural gas distribution industry segment following the requirements in subpart W.• CO2, CH4, and N2O emissions from all other applicable stationary combustion sources following the requirements of 40 CFR 98 subpart C (General Stationary Fuel Combustion Sources).

question: How are greenhouse gas emissions calculated for subpart W (oil and natural gas systems) facilities?
answer: The document mentioned several calculation methods and default emission factors for different components and services used in the calculation of greenhouse gas emissions for subpart W (oil and natural gas systems) facilities. The tables provided include Default Whole Gas Emission Factors, Default Average Component Counts for Major Onshore Natural Gas Production Equipment, Default Average Component Counts For Major Crude Oil Production Equipment, Designation Of Eastern And Western U.S., Default Whole Gas Leaker Emission Factors, Default Total Hydrocarbon Emission Factors for Onshore Natural Gas Processing Plants, Default Total Hydrocarbon Leaker Emission Factors for Onshore Natural Gas Transmission Compression, Default Total Hydrocarbon Population Emission Factors for Onshore Natural Gas Transmission Compression, Default Total Hydrocarbon Leaker Emission Factors for Underground Natural Gas Storage, Default Methane Population Emission Factors for Liquefied Natural Gas (LNG) Storage, Default Total Hydrocarbon Population Emission Factors for Underground Natural Gas Storage, and Default Methane Leaker Emission Factors for Liquefied Natural Gas (LNG) Storage. These tables provide specific emission factors and component counts for different equipment and activities within the facilities, which are used in the calculation methods described in the document. The equations mentioned in the text, such as Equation W-32A, Equation W-30, Equation W-14A, Equation W-14B, and Equation W-17A, are likely used in conjunction with these default emission factors and component counts to calculate greenhouse gas emissions for subpart W facilities.
truth: Under this rule, facilities will detect, as applicable, and calculate GHG emissions according to the specified quantification methods. See the table below for a summary of the calculation methodologies by source type. Where volumetric emissions are measured, mass emissions of CO2 and CH4 will be estimated based on the annual mole fraction and density of each GHG. • The engineering calculation methods use monitored process operating parameters and either software models, engineering calculations, or emission factors. • For emissions detection, the rule allows the use of optical gas imaging instruments, organic vapor analyzers (OVA), toxic vapor analyzers (TVA) and infrared laser beam illuminated instruments or acoustic leak detection instruments for accessible components. For inaccessible components, reporters must use an optical gas imaging instrument. • Direct measurement involves the use of the high-volume sampler; or calibrated bagging; or rotameters, turbine meters, or other meters, as appropriate, depending on the individual component for emissions measurement. • For the use of leaking factors, the relevant emission factors will be applied to leaking components determined by using an applicable instrument and applying leaking factors. For the use of population factors, the relevant emission factor will be applied to all components.

The facilities must use appropriate default emission factors for various components and equipment types and report emissions from stationary or portable fuel combustion equipment. question: When does reporting for subpart W begin?
answer: The provided text does not directly mention the specific date when reporting for subpart W begins. However, it does provide information about the requirements for facilities subject to subpart W when acquiring new sources from another facility. It states that for the first 6 months of required data collection, facilities may use best engineering estimates for any data related to those newly acquired sources that cannot reasonably be measured or obtained according to the requirements of subpart W. This indicates that the reporting for subpart W begins when facilities acquire new sources and are required to start data collection for the newly acquired sources, allowing for the use of best engineering estimates for a specific period. The text does not provide a specific numerical date or timeline for when reporting for subpart W begins.
truth: Starting in 2013 and each year thereafter, reports must be submitted to EPA by March 31 of each year, unless the 31st is a Saturday, Sunday, or federal holiday, in which case the reports are due on the next business day.  Facilities subject to subpart W must begin monitoring GHG emissions on January 1, 2011 in accordance with the methods specified in subpart W. For 2012 only, the GHG report must be submitted to EPA by September 28, 2012. This reporting deadline applies to all subparts being reported by the facility. If your subpart W facility submitted a GHG annual report for reporting year 2010 under another subpart (e.g., subpart C for general stationary fuel combustion), then by April 2, 2012 you must notify EPA through e-GGRT that you are not required to submit the second annual report until September 28, 2012 (the notification deadline according to 4 CFR 98.3(b) is March 31, 2012, however, because this date falls on a Saturday in 2012, the notification is due on the next business day).

question: In the applicability tool calculation spreadsheets, why do transmission compression and underground storage differ in the units used for vented emission from reciprocating compressor rod-packing venting?
answer: The document provides details on the calculation methods and emission factors for various equipment leaks and storage facilities. The emission factors are provided for different survey methods, such as § 98.234(a)(1) through (6) and Method 21 as specified in § 98.234(a)(7). The document also includes default average component counts for major onshore natural gas production equipment and gathering equipment, which can be used in conjunction with the emission factors to calculate emissions. Therefore, the difference in units used for vented emissions from reciprocating compressor rod-packing venting in transmission compression and underground storage is due to the different emission factors and survey methods applied in the calculation.
truth: EPA has developed the calculation spreadsheets using best available data to help industry determine applicability.  Based on the data available, EPA has developed factors on a per cylinder level and compressor level for transmission and underground storage segments, respectively.  The transmission compression tool may be used for the transmission segment and the underground storage tool for underground storage segment.  Please note that the applicability tool is intended to assist reporting facilities/owners in understanding key provisions of the rule.  They are not intended to be a substitute for the rule.

question: Will the proposed amendments to subpart W issued on June 20, 2011 that delay the due date for BAMM extension requests to December 31, 2011 be finalized before the existing deadline in the rule of July 31, 2011?
answer: The document mentioned several calculation methods which explain how to derive the emission from the data. The equations provided in the text describe the calculation of various environmental factors such as fuel-specific default CO2 emission factor, annual CO2 mass emissions, average facility-specific N2O emission factor, and more. These equations provide a detailed understanding of the calculation methods used for different environmental parameters. Additionally, the document includes several tables providing default emission factors for onshore petroleum and natural gas production facilities, average component counts for major onshore natural gas production equipment, and population emission factors for various gas services. These tables offer valuable data for calculating emissions and understanding the environmental impact of different activities. Overall, the text provides comprehensive information on the monitoring, reporting, and verification requirements related to environmental regulations, along with the necessary calculation methods and data.
truth: You are correct that on April 25, 2011, EPA finalized a rule extending the deadline for submission of a request to use BAMM until July 31, 2011 (76 FR 22825).  On June 27, 2011, a proposed rule was published in the Federal Register that would allow automatic use of BAMM for the entire 2011 reporting year for emissions sources covered under subpart W (Petroleum and Natural Gas Systems) without seeking approval from EPA (76 FR 37300).  The public comment period for the proposed rule will be open through July 27, 2011.  Given the timing necessary to consider public comment and finalize the rule, EPA will not be able to promulgate the final rule by July 31, 2011.  Please note that 40 CFR 98.234(f)(1) indicates that "If the reporter anticipates the potential need for best available monitoring for sources for which they need to petition EPA and the situation is unresolved at the time of the deadline, reporters should submit written notice of this potential situation to EPA by the specified deadline for requests to be considered."  EPA agrees that as of July 31, 2011, the circumstances surrounding the applicability of the deadline will be "unresolved" and that submitting a notification of intent would satisfy the rule requirements.

question: Do the emissions from external combustion sources with rated heat capacity equal to or less than 5 mmBtu per hour need to be included in the 25,000 metric ton threshold determination?
answer: The document specifies that external fuel combustion sources with a rated heat capacity equal to or less than 5 mmBtu/hr do not need to report combustion emissions or include these emissions for threshold determination in § 98.231(a). This indicates that emissions from external combustion sources with rated heat capacity equal to or less than 5 mmBtu per hour do not need to be included in the 25,000 metric ton threshold determination. The document also provides equations and explanations for calculating emissions, including factors such as fuel mass or volume, high heat value of the fuel, CO2 emission factor, conversion factors, and annual CO2 mass emissions from natural gas combustion. Additionally, it includes tables with emission factors for different components and equipment in onshore petroleum and natural gas production, gathering, boosting, processing, transmission compression, underground storage, and LNG storage. These tables provide detailed population emission factors and leaker emission factors for various components and equipment, which can be used in emission calculations.
truth: The emissions from external combustion equipment with a rated heat capacity of equal to or below 5 mmBtu/hr do not have to be included in the determination of reporting threshold for the facility. Please see response to comment EPA-HQ-OAR-2009-0923-1060-27, Response To Comments (1600 - 1601) http://www.epa.gov/ghgreporting/documents/pdf/2010/Subpart-W_RTC_part2.pdf.

question: Should self-propelled workover equipment and truck loading and unloading be included for reporting GHG emissions under Subpart W?
answer: The document mentioned several calculation methods and emission factors for different components and equipment related to onshore and offshore petroleum and natural gas production, gathering, boosting, and processing. truth: If the power take-off for operating the truck mounted workover rig is the truck wheel drive engine (i.e. a transmission option to transfer the truck wheel drive shaft to powering the rig generator or wench or other rig equipment) then yes, this workover rig arrangement is “self propelled.” and not required to be reported.  However, if the truck has a separate engine not connected to the drive wheels that powers the workover rig equipment, then it is “non-self propelled” and must be included in your report.

question: How do I define a facility under subpart W? Are all industry segments included in one annual GHG report?
answer: The text provides specific requirements and conditions for facilities under subpart W, including the use of best engineering estimates for data collection, reporting under different subparts, and the use of default emission factors for different types of facilities. However, it does not explicitly mention whether all industry segments are included in one annual GHG report.
truth: An onshore production facility is defined in 40 CFR 98.238 and will report only those emissions from the emissions sources listed in 40 CFR 98.232.  The onshore production facility has a single designated representative and does not include other industry segments or other source categories in its annual GHG report.  Similarly, if a facility meets the definition for natural gas distribution that facility reports only what’s listed in 98.232(i).  All other industry segments under subpart W use the definition of facility in subpart A and report emissions in a single annual GHG report.  Each facility must have one and only one designated representative.  But, the same DR could represent multiple facilities.  Other than onshore production and natural gas distribution, it is possible for a single facility to report under multiple industry segments.  Please see requirements in 98.231(a) and response to comment EPA-HQ-OAR-2009-0923-1024-14 in the EPA’s final Response to Public Comments Document for subpart W.
groundedness_reason: The answer provides information about the requirements and conditions for facilities under subpart W, but it does not explicitly mention whether all industry segments are included in one annual GHG report. Therefore, it is not possible to determine whether the answer is true or false without further information.

question: What segments of the petroleum and natural gas systems sector are covered by the current GHGRP data?
answer: The current GHGRP data covers several segments of the petroleum and natural gas systems sector, including onshore natural gas processing, onshore petroleum and natural gas production, onshore petroleum and natural gas gathering and boosting, onshore natural gas transmission compression, and onshore natural gas transmission pipeline. It also includes reporting requirements for CO2, CH4, and N2O emissions from various equipment and activities within these segments. The data collection and emissions estimation study conducted by BOEMRE in compliance with 30 CFR 250 is also referenced for offshore petroleum and natural gas production facilities. The document also mentions the option to use engineering estimates based on best available data for certain calculations, and the reporting of emissions from specific equipment/activities if they emit 25,000 metric tons of CO2 equivalent or more per year. The equations and their explanations are as follows: 1) 1.14 × 10−7= Conversion factor (lb/dscf-ppm N2O). This equation represents the conversion factor for pounds per dry standard cubic feet to parts per million of N2O. 2) MVC = Molar volume conversion factor (849.5 scf per kg-mole at standard conditions). This equation defines the molar volume conversion factor at standard conditions. 3) 2000/2205 = Conversion factor to convert tons to metric tons. This equation represents the conversion factor from tons to metric tons. 4) 44/12 = Ratio of molecular weights, CO2 to carbon. This equation calculates the ratio of molecular weights between CO2 and carbon. Additionally, the tables provide detailed population emission factors, default average component counts, and default emission factors for various equipment and activities within the petroleum and natural gas systems sector.

question: How does EPA define a "facility" for petroleum and natural gas systems?
answer: The EPA defines a 'facility' for petroleum and natural gas systems based on the equipment and activities associated with onshore petroleum and natural gas production, gathering, boosting, and processing. It includes equipment used in the production, extraction, recovery, lifting, stabilization, separation, or treating of petroleum and/or natural gas, such as compressors, generators, dehydrators, storage vessels, engines, boilers, heaters, and flares. The definition also encompasses the gathering pipelines, separators, compressors, acid gas removal units, dehydrators, pneumatic devices/pumps, and other equipment used in the collection, compression, dehydration, and transportation of petroleum and/or natural gas. The document also outlines specific reporting requirements and emission factors for different equipment types and activities within these facilities. Additionally, the document provides conversion factors, molar volume conversion factors, and population emission factors for different components and services in both Eastern and Western U.S. regions. It also includes default average component counts for major onshore natural gas production equipment, onshore petroleum and natural gas gathering and boosting equipment, and major crude oil production equipment in both regions. The tables also designate the Eastern and Western U.S. states.
truth: The definition of facility depends on each segment and the proximity of emission sources to one another.  Generally under the GHGRP a facility is all co-located emission sources that are commonly owned or operated (see the definition of “facility” in 40 CFR 98.6 for more details).

question: Did all petroleum and natural gas system facilities subject to the Greenhouse Gas Reporting Program report to EPA?
answer: The document outlines the reporting requirements for GHG emissions from petroleum and natural gas systems, including specific emission thresholds for different industry segments. It also specifies the monitoring and QA/QC requirements for offshore petroleum and natural gas production facilities. The document also mentions the reporting requirements for petroleum refineries, petrochemical processes, and suppliers of petroleum products and natural gas. It provides details on the calculation methods and reporting deadlines for different types of facilities. truth: Subpart W is a threshold based subpart and facilities are only required to report if their combined emissions from all applicable GHGRP source categories exceeded 25,000 metric tons CO2e per year.  EPA is currently in the process of reviewing the GHGRP data to determine whether all facilities subject to the requirements submitted annual reports.

question: What are the notification requirements when an Onshore Petroleum and Natural Gas Production facility, reporting under Subpart W, sells wells and associated equipment in a basin?
answer: The notification requirements for an Onshore Petroleum and Natural Gas Production facility, reporting under Subpart W, when selling wells and associated equipment in a basin, involve reporting specific information such as major equipment counts, component counts, and emissions from fuel combusted in stationary or portable equipment. The facility must also report the total annual oil/condensate throughput, the total annual oil volume from gas-liquid separators and direct from wells, and the quantities specified for onshore natural gas transmission pipeline facilities. Additionally, the facility must indicate whether any associated gas was vented or flared during the calendar year and whether the facility includes a well or group of wells where a CO2 stream was injected into subsurface geologic formations. The reporting requirements are detailed and cover various aspects of emissions and equipment associated with the production and gathering of petroleum and natural gas. The provided tables contain emission factors, default average component counts for major equipment, and other relevant data that can be used to calculate and report the required information.

The Purchaser buys all of the Seller’s wells and associated equipment in a basin where the Purchaser already operates (and the Purchaser has an e-GGRT ID).  In general, an Onshore Petroleum and Natural Gas Production facility that reports under subpart W and sold some or all of its wells and associated equipment in a basin is not required to notify EPA of the transaction. question: What are the requirements for determining the GHG mole fraction for emission calculations when a continuous gas composition analyzer is not available?

question: What are the requirements for determining the volume of gas sent to a flare?
answer: The document provides detailed requirements and calculation methods for determining the volume of gas sent to a flare. truth: The requirements are set forth at 40 CFR 98.233(n)(1).  If you have a continuous flow measurement device on the flare, you must use the measured flow volumes to calculate the flare gas emissions.  If all of the flare gas is not measured by the existing flow measurement device, then the flow not measured can be estimated using engineering calculations based on best available data or company records.  If you do not have a continuous flow measurement device on the flare, you can install a flow measuring device on the flare or use engineering calculations based on process knowledge, company records, and best available data.

question: Does the final rule amending 40 CFR Part 98 apply to both onshore and offshore petroleum and natural gas production?
answer: The final rule amending 40 CFR Part 98 applies to both onshore and offshore petroleum and natural gas production. question: Does an offshore facility reported in the GOADS 2008 that did not exceed the combined emissions threshold for subparts C and W sources of more than 25,000 metric tons CO2e have to report GHG emissions for RY2011 if emissions exceed this threshold?
answer: The document mentioned that offshore facilities must report annual emissions as calculated and reported by BOEMRE, and onshore facilities must use the most recent monitoring and calculation methods published by BOEMRE. It also outlines the conditions under which facilities must report emissions, including the threshold of 25,000 metric tons of CO2e for certain emission sources. Additionally, it mentions the use of specific calculation methods and default emission factors for different types of equipment. Therefore, if an offshore facility reported in the GOADS 2008 did not exceed the combined emissions threshold for subparts C and W sources of more than 25,000 metric tons CO2e, it would still have to report GHG emissions for RY2011 if emissions exceed this threshold, following the guidelines provided in the document.
truth: If emissions in 2011 are 25,000 tons CO2e or more for all sources covered by the greenhouse gas reporting rule, in this case sources under subparts C and W, then the facility must report. §98.233(s)(1)(i) also indicates that if the calendar year does not overlap with the most recent BOEMRE emissions study publication year, the reporter must use the most recent BOEMRE reported emission data and “adjust emissions based on the operating time for the facility relative to the operating time in the most recent BOEMRE published study.”  Therefore, if reported 2008 emissions, adjusted for any differences in 2011 operating time, are 25,000 tons CO2e or more, then the facility must report for calendar year 2011.

question: By when do onshore and offshore production facilities subject to CFR 98 Subpart W need to report?
answer: Onshore and offshore production facilities subject to CFR 98 Subpart W must report the information specified in the paragraphs (r)(3)(ii)(A) and (B) of the section. Onshore facilities must use the appropriate default whole gas leaker emission factors for components in gas service, light crude service, and heavy crude service listed in Table W–1E to this subpart. Offshore production facilities under BOEMRE jurisdiction shall report the same annual emissions as calculated and reported by BOEMRE in data collection and emissions estimation study published by BOEMRE referenced in 30 CFR 250.302 through 304 (GOADS). Offshore production facilities that are not under BOEMRE jurisdiction must use the most recent monitoring methods and calculation methods published by BOEMRE referenced in 30 CFR 250.302 through 250.304 to calculate and report annual emissions (GOADS). Facilities must report emissions from the onshore petroleum and natural gas production industry segment only if emission sources specified in § 98.232(c) emit 25,000 metric tons of CO2 equivalent or more per year.
truth: For an onshore producton facility, if the facility is subject to Subpart W in 2011, then the facility must report all combustion emissions, equipment leaks, flared emissions, and vented emissions as required under subpart W for 2011 by September 28, 2012.  For offshore production platforms, if the facility is subject to both subparts W and C in 2011, then the facility must report all combustion emissions under subpart C and all equipment leaks, flared, and vented emissions as required under subpart W for 2011 from by September 28, 2012.  If the facility submitted a report under subpart C for 2010, it is required to notify the EPA through e-GGRT by March 31, 2012 that they are not required to submit their second annual GHG report until September 28, 2012.  Any facility, as defined in 98.6, with annual stationary fuel combustion emissions greater than or equal to 25,000 metric tons CO2e in 2010 was required to report combustion emissions under subpart C by September 30, 2011.
groundedness_reason: The answer clearly states that onshore and offshore production facilities subject to CFR 98 Subpart W must report the information specified in the paragraphs (r)(3)(ii)(A) and (B) of the section. It also provides specific instructions for onshore and offshore facilities to calculate and report their annual emissions. question: Are the emissions factors listed in Table W-1A for both leaking components and non-leaking components? How do you calculate emissions from leaking components if onshore petroleum and natural gas source are not required to monitor components?
answer: The emissions factors listed in Table W-1A are indeed used for both leaking and non-leaking components. For onshore petroleum and natural gas sources, the emissions from leaking components are not required to be monitored, and the appropriate default whole gas population emission factors from Table W-1A are used for these facilities. The Table W-1A provides emission factors for various components in onshore petroleum and natural gas production and gathering facilities, while Table W-1E provides emission factors for leaking components in the same facilities. The emission factors from Table W-1E are used when surveying using specific methods as specified in § 98.234(a)(1) through (7). The emission factors from Table W-1A are used as default whole gas population emission factors for facilities where monitoring of leaking components is not required.

question: Are geologic provinces 160 and 160A one basin or separate basins for the purposes of defining a facility for onshore petroleum and natural gas production?
answer: Geologic provinces 160 and 160A are considered one basin for the purposes of defining a facility for onshore petroleum and natural gas production. question: Why did EPA require that facilities conducting onshore petroleum and natural gas production report by basin?
answer: The EPA required that facilities conducting onshore petroleum and natural gas production report by basin in order to accurately track and regulate emissions from these facilities. This requirement is based on the understanding that emissions can vary significantly by geographic location. By reporting emissions data by basin, the EPA can better monitor and regulate the environmental impact of onshore petroleum and natural gas production. This approach allows for more targeted and effective regulatory measures to mitigate the environmental impact of these activities. The provided tables contain population emission factors for different components and equipment used in onshore petroleum and natural gas production, which can be used to calculate and estimate emissions from these facilities in different basins. Additionally, the designation of Eastern and Western U.S. states provides a geographical context for the regulatory reporting requirements, as emissions can vary between these regions.
truth: When the GHGRP requirements for onshore petroleum and natural gas production were proposed, EPA’s goal was to provide a facility definition that all producers could directly apply, and that would be both practical and cost-effective.  EPA sought public comment on a range of possible options for defining the facility that would report with respect to onshore petroleum and natural gas production, ranging from defining the facility at the individual well pad, to defining the facility at the field-level, to defining the facility at the basin-level.  Taking into account public comment, EPA finalized the definition of facility with respect to onshore petroleum and natural gas production using a basin-level approach because the operational boundaries and basin demarcations are clearly defined and are widely known, and the approach covered most emissions from onshore petroleum and natural gas production.
groundedness_reason: The answer provides a clear and accurate explanation of why the EPA required facilities conducting onshore petroleum and natural gas production to report by basin. The answer also correctly identifies the tables provided as containing population emission factors for different components and equipment used in onshore petroleum and natural gas production, which can be used to estimate emissions from these facilities in different basins. Finally, the answer correctly notes that the designation of Eastern and Western U.S. states provides a geographical context for the regulatory reporting requirements, as emissions can vary between these regions.

answer: The text provides information about onshore petroleum and natural gas gathering and boosting, including the definition of gathering and boosting systems, equipment, and facilities. It also mentions the gas to oil ratio (GOR) for gathering pipelines, specifying that gathering pipelines with a GOR less than 300 standard cubic feet per stock tank barrel (scf/STB) are not included in the industry segment. Additionally, it outlines methods for determining emissions from blowdown vent stacks and calculation methodologies for various equipment, such as gas-liquid separators and glycol dehydrators. The text also discusses the determination of GOR for hydrocarbon production from oil and gas wells, including options for using engineering estimates based on the best available data. The provided tables include population emission factors for gathering pipelines in the Eastern and Western U.S., default average component counts for major onshore natural gas production equipment and onshore petroleum and natural gas gathering and boosting equipment, default whole gas leaker emission factors, default total hydrocarbon emission factors for onshore natural gas processing, default total hydrocarbon leaker emission factors for underground natural gas storage, default methane leaker emission factors for liquefied natural gas (LNG) storage, default methane population emission factors for LNG storage compressor, and default methane emission factors for natural gas distribution. These tables provide specific emission factors and component counts that can be used in the calculation of emissions and GOR for gathering pipelines and other equipment in the petroleum and natural gas industry.
truth: The gathering and boosting system owner or operator can use a direct measurement of GOR through either onsite measurement or by sending samples out for laboratory analysis. The timing and duration of the sampling/measurement program should follow existing regulatory requirements, which include standard methods published by a consensus-based standards organization or industry standard practices. See 40 CFR 98.234(b). The EPA realizes that owners or operators may calculate GOR for other reasons such as documenting fluid quality for financial transactions, equipment optimization or other state/federal reporting requirements. These values can be used where appropriate.A825. 40 CFR Part 98, Subpart W does not prescribe a specific approach to calculate GOR. Gathering and boosting system operators may use the best approach for their facility, including direct measurement, calculation from other measured data, and standard estimation measures. We note that within the EPA’s 2016 updates to New Source Performance Standards for the oil and natural gas sector, GOR is defined as the ratio of the volume of gas at standard temperature and pressure that is produced from a volume of oil when depressurized to a standard temperature and pressure. See 40 CFR 60.5430a.

question: My gathering pipeline is exempt based on Gas to Oil Ratio. Does the exemption only apply to the pipeline itself, or is all equipment along the pipeline excluded as well?
answer: The document provides detailed information on the Gas to Oil Ratio (GOR) and its calculation, as well as the reporting requirements for emissions from onshore petroleum and natural gas gathering and boosting industry segment. It also includes calculation methodologies for estimating CO2 emissions and the exemption threshold of 25,000 metric tons of CO2 equivalent per year for various industry segments. The document outlines the calculation methods for estimating CO2 emissions from petroleum products and natural gas liquids, as well as the calculation of annual CH4 and CO2 emissions from various equipment and facilities. However, it does not explicitly mention whether the exemption based on Gas to Oil Ratio applies only to the pipeline itself or to all equipment along the pipeline. The document also includes several equations for calculating emissions, such as the fuel-specific default CO2 emission factor (EF) from Table C–1 of the subpart, which is used in the equation E = Fuel * EF to derive the CO2 emissions. Additionally, there are tables providing emission factors for different components and equipment in the onshore petroleum and natural gas production and gathering segments, which can be used in the emission calculation process. However, the specific application of the exemption based on Gas to Oil Ratio to the pipeline or all equipment along the pipeline is not explicitly addressed in the provided information.
truth: As defined in 40 CFR 98.230(a)(9), the exclusion only applies to individual gathering pipelines with a GOR of less than 300 scf/STB, not any other part of the gathering and boosting system.

question: Can facilities covered by the Subpart W Onshore Petroleum and Natural Gas Gathering and Boosting industry segment use Subpart C emission factors for calculating combustion emissions?
answer: The document provides detailed information about the onshore petroleum and natural gas gathering and boosting industry segment. It specifies that facilities in this industry segment must use the appropriate default whole gas leaker factors for components in gas service listed in Table W–1E to this subpart. The document also outlines the reporting requirements, stating that facilities must report emissions from this industry segment only if emission sources emit 25,000 metric tons of CO2 equivalent or more per year. However, it does not explicitly mention whether facilities covered by the Subpart W Onshore Petroleum and Natural Gas Gathering and Boosting industry segment can use Subpart C emission factors for calculating combustion emissions. The provided text also contains various equations and their explanations, which cover a wide range of factors such as carbon dioxide equivalent, calibration error, destruction efficiency, conversion factors, and ratios of molecular weights. These equations are used to calculate emissions, conversion factors, and efficiency in various industrial processes related to environmental regulations.
truth: Combustion emissions for the Onshore Petroleum and Natural Gas Gathering and Boosting segment are calculated using methods outlined in 40 CFR 98.233(z). Those methods provide flexibility to use Subpart C emission factors if the fuel combusted is natural gas, is pipeline quality, and has a minimum high heat value of 950 Btu per standard cubic foot. If the fuel meets those criteria, then you may use the emission factor for natural gas as listed in 40 CFR Part 98, Subpart C, Table C-1.  See 40 CFR 98.233(z)(1).

question: Section 98.230(a)(3) states that processing plants "that do not fractionate but have an annual average throughput of 25 MMscf per day or greater" are included in the source category. Is this based on annual average daily flow or max design capacity?
answer: Section 98.230(a)(3) states that processing plants 'that do not fractionate but have an annual average throughput of 25 MMscf per day or greater' are included in the source category. This inclusion is based on the annual average throughput of natural gas and not the maximum design capacity. The provided input also contains tables related to emission factors for various components in onshore natural gas processing plants, as well as the designation of Eastern and Western U.S. states. However, there is no specific mention of the calculation method or formula for determining the annual average throughput of natural gas in the given text.
truth: The gas processing plant throughput threshold in 98.230(a)(3) is based on annual average throughput.
groundedness_reason: The answer provides a direct and accurate response to the question by citing the relevant section of the text and explicitly stating that the inclusion is based on the annual average throughput of natural gas and not the maximum design capacity.

question: What is the definition of  "fractionate" and "fractionation" in 98.230(a)(3)?

question: Under onshore natural gas processing where are vent emissions reported?
answer: Vent emissions from onshore natural gas processing are reported for CO2, CH4, and N2O. The document also provides default emission factors for various components and equipment used in onshore petroleum and natural gas production and gathering facilities. The emission factors are categorized based on different regions and equipment types. For example, the document includes emission factors for valve, connector, open-ended line, pressure relief valve, pneumatic pumps, and other components. These emission factors can be used in the calculation methods for reporting emissions from onshore natural gas processing. Additionally, the document provides average component counts for major onshore natural gas production equipment and gathering equipment, which can be used in conjunction with the emission factors to estimate vent emissions. The emission factors are also provided for leaker components and total hydrocarbon emissions, which can be used in the reporting of vent emissions from onshore natural gas processing.
truth: If a membrane unit is used to remove CO2 from natural gas containing concentrations of hydrogen sulfide or carbon dioxide that exceed the concentrations specified for commercially saleable nature gas, then emissions must be calculated and reported as specified in §98.233 (d), as this process meets the definition of acid gas removal unit in §98.238.  Please see EPA-HQ-OAR-2009-0923-1298-18 in the Response To Comments (1719 - 1720) http://www.epa.gov/ghgreporting/documents/pdf/2010/Subpart-W_RTC_part2.pdf for further details on the definitions of sweet and sour gas.

question: If a natural gas processing plant is co-located with an underground storage facility and they share compression, can they report as one combined facility?
answer: The document specifies that if a natural gas processing plant and an underground storage facility share compression equipment, they can report as one combined facility. This is because the underground natural gas storage includes compression, dehydration, and flow measurement, and all the wellheads connected to the compression units located at the facility that inject and recover natural gas into and from the underground reservoirs. Therefore, the sharing of compression equipment allows them to be considered as one combined facility for reporting purposes.
truth: If the natural gas processing plant and the underground storage operations are part of the same facility, as defined in 98.6 you would report as one facility and submit one annual GHG report for these operations.  EPA has provided guidance on how reporters should report for co-located industry segments and dual purpose equipment, please see the comment response number EPA-HQ-OAR-2009-0923-1024-14, Response To Comments (1606 - 1608) http://www.epa.gov/ghgreporting/documents/pdf/2010/Subpart-W_RTC_part2.pdf.
groundedness_reason: The answer logically follows from the information provided in the context. It explicitly states that if a natural gas processing plant and an underground storage facility share compression equipment, they can report as one combined facility. The provided answer also explains why this is the case, as the underground natural gas storage includes compression, dehydration, and flow measurement, and all the wellheads connected to the compression units located at the facility that inject and recover natural gas into and from the underground reservoirs.
dontknowness_reason: The answer completely answers the question and conveys no uncertainty.
coherence_reason: The answer is well-structured and all the sentences fit together naturally. It provides a clear and concise explanation of the conditions under which a natural gas processing plant and an underground storage facility can report as one combined facility, based on the sharing of compression equipment.

question: If fuel gas lines are not owned or operated by a gas processing facility, but are on the gas processing facility property, do the fuel gas lines need to be monitored for equipment leaks?
answer: The text provides information on default emission factors for various components and equipment in different gas services, such as gas production, gathering, boosting, and transmission compression. The information presented in the tables can be used to calculate the total hydrocarbon emissions and to determine whether fuel gas lines on the gas processing facility property need to be monitored for equipment leaks.
truth: The definition of facility in 98.6 requires equipment to be under “common ownership or common control.”  Therefore, based on the information provided, the fuel gas lines are not subject to the rule because they are not owned and/or operated by the reporting gas processing facility’s owners/operators.

question: Please confirm that a facility which processes an inlet gas stream with a methane content of less than 70% by volume, and a heating value of less than 910 Btu per standard cubic foot is excluded from the Onshore Natural Gas Processing segment.
answer: The document does not contain specific information about the exclusion criteria for the Onshore Natural Gas Processing segment based on methane content and heating value of the inlet gas stream. The tables include data such as population emission factors, leaker emission factors, and methane emission factors for various components and services. While the document contains valuable information related to emissions and equipment, it does not directly address the exclusion criteria mentioned in the question.
truth: The definition of “natural gas” in the final rule revision (December 23, 2011) excludes the composition and heat value specification and simply states: “Natural gas means a naturally occurring mixture or process derivative of hydrocarbon and non-hydrocarbon gases found in geologic formations beneath the earth's surface, of which its constituents include, but are not limited to, methane, heavier hydrocarbons and carbon dioxide.  Natural gas may be field quality, pipeline quality, or process gas.”  Based upon the finalized definition of “natural gas”, a facility that processes an inlet gas stream which is field gas could be included in the Onshore Natural Gas Processing segment if the process otherwise meets the definition of Onshore Natural Gas Processing.

answer: The document provides detailed information about the regulations and calculations related to natural gas facilities. It mentions that facilities designed solely to fractionate natural gas liquid streams and do not receive a gaseous form of natural gas containing methane are subject to subpart W. It outlines the calculation methodology for estimating CO2 emissions from the complete combustion or oxidation of NGL products supplied. question: How should I calculate the reporting threshold for onshore natural gas processing plants that do not fractionate gas liquids?
answer: The document provides information on how to calculate the reporting threshold for onshore natural gas processing plants that do not fractionate gas liquids but have an annual average throughput of 25 MMscf per day or greater. It states that the reporting threshold should be based on the annual volumes in Mscf of natural gas received for processing. Additionally, it mentions the use of GHG mole fraction in feed natural gas for emissions sources upstream of the de-methanizer or dew point control, and GHG mole fraction in facility specific residue gas to transmission pipeline systems for emissions sources downstream of the de-methanizer overhead or dew point control for onshore natural gas processing facilities. However, the document does not provide specific equations or calculations for deriving the reporting threshold. It does include tables with population emission factors, default average component counts, total hydrocarbon emission factors, and total hydrocarbon leaker emission factors for onshore natural gas processing, which may be used in conjunction with the mentioned information to calculate the reporting threshold.
truth: The Rule states in §98.230(a) that the onshore natural gas processing industry includes all plants that fractionate, as well as all plants that do not fractionate that have an annual average throughput of 25 MMscf per day or greater.  Only those non-fractionating facilities with an annual average throughput of less than 25 MMscf per day would not be subject to reporting under subpart W even if the reporting threshold is triggered in Subpart C.  The gas processing plant throughput threshold in 98.230(a)(3) is based on annual average throughput.

question: What is the basis for the 25 MMscfd threshold for gas processing facilities in 98.230(a)(3) and how often must a facility re-evaluate whether it falls below this threshold?
answer: The 25 MMscfd threshold for gas processing facilities in 98.230(a)(3) is based on the annual average throughput. Facilities that do not fractionate gas liquids but have an annual average throughput of 25 MMscf per day or greater are included in the industry segment. The frequency of re-evaluating whether a facility falls below this threshold is not explicitly mentioned in the provided text.
truth: However, please note that if, in year 2, your throughput capacity is less than 25 MMscf per day, you are not required to calculate and report GHG emissions from gas processing in year 2.  You would still be required to report other covered emissions at your facility.  This is because gas processing would not be an applicable segment for year 2.  Nevertheless, your facility would still be required to report in year 2, even if facility-wide emissions are less than 25,000mt CO2e, and would continue to report until you meet the criteria in 98.2(i) for ceasing to report.  The gas processing plant throughput threshold in 98.230(a)(3) is based on annual average throughput.  This throughput is re-evaluated annually.  Once you are subject to the rule (e.g., your facility contains a source category listed in Table A-4), your facility must continue complying with all the requirements of this part, even if the facility does not meet the applicability requirements in a future year (i.e., 25,000 mtCO2e for petroleum and natural gas systems). The definition of the source category for petroleum and natural gas systems, under onshore natural gas processing, refers to a processing facility that does not fractionate and has a throughput of 25MMscf per day or greater.  Because a gas processing facility that is over 25 MMscf per day meets the definition of the source category for subpart W, any facility that becomes subject to the rule in whole or in part because of a natural gas processing facility, would have to continue reporting until it meets the conditions for cessation of reporting in 98.2(i).

question: What is the difference between the methods in 98.233(k) and 98.234(a)(1) for monitoring tank emissions?  How do we treat intermittent emission from the storage tank? Can we use an alternative method to quantify the emissions?
answer: The methods for monitoring tank emissions are specified in 98.233(k) and 98.234(a)(1). Method 98.233(k) requires monitoring the tank vapor vent stack annually for emissions using specified methods, while method 98.234(a)(1) requires continuous monitoring of the flow rate, CH4 concentration, temperature, pressure, and moisture content. Intermittent emissions from the storage tank can be treated by calculating the weekly CH4 liberated from the mine using CH4 measured weekly or more frequently, CH4 content, flow rate, temperature, pressure, and moisture content. An alternative method to quantify the emissions can be used if it complies with the requirements specified in the regulations. The document also provides default population emission factors and leaker emission factors for various components and services, which can be used in the quantification of emissions. Additionally, it includes default average component counts for major onshore natural gas production equipment and crude oil production equipment, as well as the designation of Eastern and Western U.S. states for reference. These tables and factors can be utilized to calculate and quantify emissions as per the given regulations.
truth: The purpose of this detection and measurement is to determine and quantify any continuous gas emissions from condensate storage tanks.  The most common source of vapor emissions from a transmission compressor station condensate tank would be liquid transfer from compressor scrubber dump valves.  These sources operating properly would be intermittent transfer of liquids from high pressure vessels to an atmospheric storage tank, with a short term flashing of dissolved gas, which is assumed to be less than 5 minutes in duration.  Malfunction of scrubber dump valves can result in high pressure vapor leaking through the valve, into the condensate tank, and out the tank roof vent, which would vent indefinitely.  This continuous release of vapor is detected as a continuous blow of gas from the condensate tank roof vent using a leak imaging camera or by using an acoustic through-valve leak detection instrument.  Based on the current rule, when using an optical gas imaging instrument, the tank needs to be monitored to determine whether the tank vapors are continuous for 5 minutes; see section 98.233(k)(2).  So if a leak is detected per requirements of 98.234(a)(1) and is continuous per the requirements of 98.233(k)(2) then the reporter has to measure the emissions per requirements in 98.233(k)(2)(i)-(iv).  The reporter has the choice of using an acoustic leak detection device to detect and measure leaks per requirements in 98.234(a)(5).  You cannot use alternative methods to those outlined in the rule.
relevance_reason: The answer provides a clear and accurate explanation of the difference between the two methods for monitoring tank emissions, as well as how intermittent emissions from the storage tank can be treated and the possibility of using alternative methods to quantify emissions. The answer also mentions the availability of default population emission factors and leaker emission factors for various components and services, as well as average component counts for major equipment and the designation of Eastern and Western U.S. states for reference, which shows a comprehensive understanding of the regulations and their application.

question: How does a natural gas compressor station that operates compressors for natural gas transmission and an emergency generator determine subpart applicability?
answer: The document provides information on how a natural gas compressor station that operates compressors for natural gas transmission and an emergency generator determines subpart applicability. It mentions that the emissions of CO2, CH4, and N2O from stationary or portable fuel combustion equipment, natural gas dehydrators, natural gas compressors, electrical generators, steam boilers, and process heaters are reported under the subpart. Additionally, it discusses the use of default total hydrocarbon leaker emission factors for compressor components in gas service and non-compressor components in gas service. The document also outlines the calculation methods for volumetric GHG emissions from reciprocating compressor venting at onshore petroleum and natural gas production facilities or onshore petroleum and natural gas gathering and boosting facilities. Furthermore, it provides tables with default whole gas emission factors, average component counts for major onshore natural gas production equipment, default total hydrocarbon emission factors for onshore natural gas processing, and default total hydrocarbon leaker emission factors for onshore natural gas transmission compression. These tables contain specific emission factors and component counts for different equipment and activities, which can be used to determine subpart applicability based on the type of equipment and activities specified in the relevant paragraphs.
truth: For the purpose of determining the applicability of 40 CFR part 98 for the 2010 reporting year, the facility should calculate the emissions from the gas compressors pursuant to 40 CFR 98.30(a)(2). So long as a the emergency generators meet the definition of “emergency equipment” as stated in 98.6, emissions from the emergency generators are exempt and should not be calculated.  If the facility is subject to 40 CFR part 98, you should report combustion emissions pursuant to the applicable requirements of subpart C (General Stationary Fuel Combustion Sources).  Pursuant to 40 CFR 98.2, if a facility’s calculated total annual emissions are less than 25,000 metric tons of CO2e and the facility does not contain a source category listed in Table A-3 of 40 CFR part 98, subpart A, then the facility does not have to report under 40 CFR part 98 as a direct emitter.

question: How do we report emissions from separate facilities that inject or withdraw gas from the same underground storage reservoir?
answer: The document provides detailed information on reporting emissions from various facilities, including underground natural gas storage. question: What is the definition of "facility" for underground storage?
answer: The definition of 'facility' for underground storage includes subsurface storage of natural gas in depleted gas or oil reservoirs and salt dome caverns, processes and operations such as compression, dehydration, and flow measurement, as well as wellheads connected to the compression units located at the facility that inject and recover natural gas into and from the underground reservoirs.
truth: A “facility”, as defined in 40 CFR 98.6, must determine if it contains any of the industry segments listed in subpart W and compare its emissions against the 25,000 mtCO2e threshold defined in 40 CFR 98.2(a)(2) to determine applicability.  Underground natural gas storage is as defined in §98.230(a)(5) and includes reporting of GHGs as listed in §98.232(f)(1) through (5).  Therefore, the reporter needs to determine all applicable sources as per this industry segment definition and sources to report.  Specifically, filters and separators are not listed as sources under 98.232(f)(1) through (5) but if filters or separators are associated with any sources under this section, reporting of those listed sources is still required.  The sources required to report under the underground storage source category are listedin §98.232(f).  In this list dehydration units are not included therefore reporting from this source type is not required.

This information is logically entailed by the provided context.

question: Does Subpart W require reporting of emissions during the salt dome mining process to create an underground natural gas storage facility or does reporting start only when natural gas is introduced for load balancing or storage?
answer: Subpart W requires reporting of emissions during the salt dome mining process to create an underground natural gas storage facility. Reporting starts when natural gas is introduced for load balancing or storage. question: How should we report a facility that combines onshore petroleum and natural gas production and natural gas storage by injecting natural gas for the purposes of both enhanced oil recoveray and storage?
answer: The document provides detailed information about onshore petroleum and natural gas production, natural gas storage, and enhanced oil recovery (EOR) using CO2 or natural gas injection. It explains the equipment and activities involved in these processes, including gathering pipelines, compressors, dehydrators, storage vessels, and separators. It also outlines the reporting requirements for emissions from various sources, such as storage tanks, natural gas processing, and transmission compression. The document emphasizes the importance of calculating and reporting greenhouse gas emissions, including CO2, CH4, and N2O, from different equipment and activities. It also highlights the distinction between onshore and offshore production, as well as the regulations for reporting emissions from different industry segments. Overall, it provides a comprehensive overview of the regulatory framework and reporting obligations for facilities combining onshore petroleum and natural gas production with natural gas storage and enhanced oil recovery using injection methods. Additionally, the document includes tables with population emission factors, default average component counts for major equipment, and default total hydrocarbon emission factors for various processes, which can be used to calculate and report emissions from the mentioned activities.
truth: What constitutes a facility, how to determine the reporting threshold, and reporting of emissions from collocated and dual purpose equipment is as follows: 1) As a first step the reporter must determine the emissions from all equipment listed in 98.232(c) for onshore petroleum and production.  Per section 98.231(a) only sources listed in 98.232(c) need to be considered for threshold determination for onshore petroleum and natural gas production. 98.238 defines “facility” for the purposes of onshore petroleum and natural gas systems.  Per the requirements of 98.3 each “facility” must submit a GHG report for all source categories at that “facility”.  2) Note that while identifying onshore production emissions sources reporters have to determine whether the source is “on the well pad or associated with a well pad”.  The location of production wells within other facilities is inconsequential to this determination.  Sources on a well pad or associated with a well pad across the entire reporting basin have to be taken into consideration.  If your emissions from onshore petroleum and natural gas production are equal to or greater than 25,000mtCO2e, then onshore petroleum and natural gas production facilities report as a separate facility and include all emissions sources listed in 98.232(c).  3) Except for onshore petroleum and natural gas production and natural gas distribution, which have unique facility definitions, all other segments subject to subpart W are considered in the threshold determination for a single facility.  You would also include emissions from other source categories at your facility (e.g., stationary combustion).  If there are emissions sources that are dual purpose then the rule requires this piece of equipment to be reported under the majority use industry segment based on guidance provided in EPA-HQ-OAR-2009-0923-1024-14 (pp. 1606-1608).  4) For collocated industry segments, which cannot occur in the case of onshore petroleum and natural gas production and natural gas distribution due to the requirements in 98.231(a), EPA has provided guidance on emissions reporting in EPA-HQ-OAR-2009-0923-1024-14.  Based on the information provided, the facility cannot be reported as onshore production and natural gas processing combined (see point 1 above).  For all the other segments, the report should use guidance in points 2-3 above to determine the segment under which the facility should be categorized.

question: For liquefied natural gas facility equipment that is in gas service, is only the equipment listed in Table W-5 (Vapor Recovery Compressor) required to be reported if it is found to be leaking as defined in the rule?
answer: For liquefied natural gas (LNG) facility equipment that is in gas service, only the equipment listed in Table W-5 (Vapor Recovery Compressor) is required to be reported if it is found to be leaking as defined in the rule. The given information does not directly mention the specific requirement for reporting leaking equipment. truth: LNG facilities will not be surveying the valves, connectors, and other components that are in Gas Service under 98.233(q).  At an LNG facility, a compressor that recovers vapor, but is designed so that it does not have reportable emissions of methane-containing gas, such as a flooded screw compressor, or one with seals purged with pressurized nitrogen, will not be reported, in accordance with the rule and the EPA’s response in Response to Public Comments, EPA-HQ-OAR-2009-0923-1026-7 (see pp. 45-46 in http://www.epa.gov/ghgreporting/documents/pdf/2010/Subpart-W_RTC_part1.pdf).  Vapor recovery compressors use a population emission factor, hence there is no leak detection required.  Reporters have to count the number of vapor recovery compressors and use the population emission factor.
