question: Please explain how many leak detection surveys must be conducted a calendar year?  Must a facility indicate in advance how many surveys will be conducted in the year?
answer: The document specifies that at least one leak detection survey must be conducted in a calendar year. If multiple complete leak detection surveys are conducted in a calendar year, the results from each survey must be used when calculating emissions. The number of surveys to be conducted in a year is not explicitly specified and does not need to be indicated in advance. This means that while at least one survey is mandatory, facilities have the flexibility to conduct multiple surveys as needed. The document also outlines various leak detection methods and equipment leak survey requirements for different components, along with reporting obligations. It provides details on the use of specific leak detection devices and methods, as well as the calculation methodology for equipment leak emissions. Additionally, it mentions the option for natural gas distribution facilities to conduct equipment leak surveys across a multiple-year cycle, with specific reporting requirements for such facilities. The provided tables contain default emission factors and component counts for different regions, which can be used in the calculation methodology for equipment leak emissions.
truth: For natural gas distribution, a facility, which is the collection of all distribution pipelines, metering stations, and regulating stations that are operated by an LDC, is required to do at least one facility wide leak detection survey per calendar year and has the option to conduct additional facility-wide leak detection surveys; if the facility selects this option, the additional facility-wide survey(s) must be completed during the same calendar year in order to account for fixing one or more leaks in the annual GHG report.  If the facility chooses to fix one or more leaks and conduct another survey to determine that the component is not leaking, it must conduct a facility wide leak detection survey in order to account for fixing the leak(s) in the annual GHG report.  As leaks are random in nature and while some leaks are fixed others are likely to occur.  Therefore, a comprehensive survey is the only statistically relevant manner by which to establish facility-wide leak emissions rates and account for leaks repaired.  Please see the response to comment EPA-HQ-OAR-2009-0923-1014-9 (Response to Comments, pp. 1281-1282, http://www.epa.gov/ghgreporting/documents/pdf/2010/Subpart-W_RTC_part2.pdf) for further details.  It is very important to note that the requirement to conduct additional facility-wide leak detection surveys should a company wish to account for fixing a leak does not preclude in any way a company from repairing a leak.  If a company chooses to conduct only one facility-wide leak detection survey in a calendar year but finds a leak during the survey, the company can and is encouraged to fix the leak.  The leak detected though, as noted above, must be reported as a leaker for the entire calendar year should the company choose not to conduct a second survey.
groundedness_reason: The answer states that at least one leak detection survey must be conducted in a calendar year and that the number of surveys to be conducted in a year is not explicitly specified and does not need to be indicated in advance. question: Would a monitoring plan that results in 10% of stations being monitored in each of years 1 and 2, 40% in year 3, 20% in year 4 and 20% in year five, be consistent with the rule language of "approximately equal across all years in the cycle."

EPA’s objection to the comment to monitor 10% of stations per year would have been inconsistent with a five-year cycle.  Yes.   According to 98.233(q)(8)(i), “Natural gas distribution facilities may choose to conduct leak detection at T-D transfer stations over multiple years, not exceeding a five year period to cover all T-D transfer stations.  If the facility chooses to use the multiple year option, then the number of T-D transfer stations monitored in each year should be approximately equal across all years in the cycle without monitoring the same station twice during the multiple year survey.”  EPA confirms that an approach of conducting monitoring at 10% of the facilities in each of the first two years, followed by 40%, 20% and 20% in years three, four and five would be consistent with the rule language that the number of stations monitored be “approximately equal” over the number of years surveyed.

question: What types of instruments are permissible for use in detecting equipment leaks and through valve leakage in Subpart W?
answer: The document mentions the permissible instruments for detecting equipment leaks and through valve leakage in Subpart W. These instruments include Method 21, equipment leak detection methods in appendix A–7 to part 60 of this chapter, acoustic leak detection device, optical gas imaging instrument, and infrared laser beam illuminated instrument. Method 21 specifies that a leak is detected if an instrument reading of 10,000 ppm or greater is measured. The acoustic leak detection device is used to detect through-valve leakage, and a leak is detected if a leak of 3.1 scf per hour or greater is calculated. The optical gas imaging instrument is used for inaccessible source types, and a leak is designated if 10,000 ppm or greater is measured. Additionally, the infrared laser beam illuminated instrument is used for equipment leak detection, and a leak is designated if 10,000 ppm or greater is measured. The document also provides various calculation methodologies for equipment leak emissions and the reporting of survey information for equipment leaks. It includes equations for emission factors, molar volume conversion factor, ratio of molecular weights, conversion factors for various units, and mass of emitted gases from process vents. Furthermore, the document contains tables with population emission factors for different regions, default average component counts for major equipment, designation of Eastern and Western U.S., default whole gas leaker emission factors, default total hydrocarbon emission factors for onshore natural gas processing, default total hydrocarbon leaker emission factors for onshore natural gas transmission compression, and default total hydrocarbon leaker emission factors for underground natural gas storage.
context:
The permissible instruments for detecting equipment leaks and through valve leakage in Subpart W include Method 21, equipment leak detection methods in appendix A–7 to part 60 of this chapter, acoustic leak detection device, optical gas imaging instrument, and infrared laser beam illuminated instrument. Method 21 specifies that a leak is detected if an instrument reading of 10,000 ppm or greater is measured. The acoustic leak detection device is used to detect through-valve leakage, and a leak is detected if a leak of 3.1 scf per hour or greater is calculated. The optical gas imaging instrument is used for inaccessible source types and a leak is designated if 10,000 ppm or greater is measured. Additionally, the infrared laser beam illuminated instrument is used for equipment leak detection, and a leak is designated if 10,000 ppm or greater is measured. truth: For conducting leak detection required by subpart W, reporters have the option to use optical gas imaging instruments, infrared laser beam illuminated instruments, or acoustic leak detection devices as outlined in 40 CFR 98.234(a).  In addition, reporters may use other instruments, however those instruments must comply with the provisions as stated in 40 CFR 98.234(a)(2).

question: Can data from a state permit-required fugitive emissions monitoring program already in place, which has a lower leak detection rate of 500 ppm, be used to estimate fugitive greenhouse gas emissions under §98.233(q)?
answer: The document provides detailed information about the requirements and methods for reporting fugitive emissions and equipment leak surveys under §98.233(q). It outlines the components subject to well site or compressor station fugitive emissions standards, the leak detection methods to be used, and the procedures for calculating equipment leak emissions. It also specifies the conditions under which data from a state permit-required fugitive emissions monitoring program with a lower leak detection rate of 500 ppm can be used to estimate fugitive greenhouse gas emissions under §98.233(q)(1)(iv). The document also includes several equations and explanations related to the calculation of emissions from fuel combustion, CO2 emissions, and natural gas usage. Additionally, it provides tables containing default emission factors for various components and equipment counts for major onshore natural gas production and crude oil production equipment. These tables can be used to estimate fugitive greenhouse gas emissions under §98.233(q) by incorporating the emission factors and equipment counts into the relevant calculation methods.

question: Does 98.233(q), "Leak detection and leaker emission factors," apply to wellheads, separators at well site, storage tanks and other equipment defined by "production equipment"?
answer: The regulation 98.233(q) does apply to wellheads, separators at well site, storage tanks, and other equipment defined by 'production equipment' as it covers equipment leaks from valves, connectors, open-ended lines, and pressure relief valves associated with storage wellheads, as well as onshore petroleum and natural gas production equipment, including compressors, generators, dehydrators, storage vessels, engines, boilers, heaters, flares, separation and processing equipment, and portable non-self-propelled equipment. The document also provides default whole gas emission factors for onshore petroleum and natural gas production facilities and onshore petroleum and natural gas gathering and boosting facilities, average component counts for major onshore natural gas production equipment, major crude oil production equipment, and guidelines for reporting emissions from different equipment components. The emission factors and component counts can be used to calculate emissions from different equipment types as specified in the regulation.
truth: Onshore production reporters do not need to perform leak detection under §98.233(q) for equipment leaks.  For an onshore petroleum and natural gas production facility, equipment leaks are calculated with the methodology in §98.233(r), using population count and population emissions factors.

question: Do acid gas removal units which are used only to sweeten a liquid stream meet the definition of acid gas removal units?
answer: The text provides detailed information about acid gas removal units (AGR) and the calculation methods for CO2 emissions from AGR vents. truth: The definition of acid gas removal unit in §98.238 states, “process unit that separates hydrogen sulfide and/or carbon dioxide from sour natural gas using liquid or solid absorbents or membrane separators.”  Acid gas removal units processing a liquid stream do not meet this definition, and reporters do not need to report emissions from these units.

question: If all of the emissions from an AGR unit are recovered and transferred outside of the facility, does the facility still need to calculate emissions pursuant to Section 98.233(d)(11) and then "reduce" the emission to zero?
answer: The document mentioned several calculation methods for determining CO2 emissions from different equipment and components in the petroleum and natural gas industry. truth: With regards to acid gas injection wells and subparts PP and UU, please see the response to EPA-HQ-OAR-2009-0923-0582-31 in the Response to Comments (pages 1474 - 1476) http://www.epa.gov/ghgreporting/documents/pdf/2010/Subpart-W_RTC_part2.pdf.  EPA requires reporters to calculate emissions from AGR units and then adjust them downwards by the amount transferred outside of the facility.  Therefore, if 100% of the CO2 recovered from an AGR unit is transferred outside of the facility, then CO2 emissions from the AGR unit must be calculated prior to determining the amount being transferred outside the facility.  Note that §98.236(c)(3) requires separate reporting of both the AGR emissions and emissions recovered and transferred outside the facility, even if the values are the same.

question: Will EPA approve the use of BAMM relating to the measurement of isolation valves at compressors in the shut down depressurized mode that are to be measured at least once every three calendar years?
answer: The document specifies the requirements for measuring volumetric emissions from isolation valve leakage at compressors in not-operating-depressurized-mode. It outlines the frequency of measurement, stating that it must be done at least once in any three consecutive calendar years, provided it can be taken during a scheduled shutdown. If there is no scheduled shutdown within three consecutive calendar years, the measurement must be taken at the next scheduled depressurized shutdown. The requirement does not apply if the compressor has blind flanges in place throughout the reporting year. Additionally, the document provides methods for performing as found measurements from individual centrifugal and reciprocating compressor sources, and it outlines the general requirements for conducting volumetric emission measurements on each centrifugal and reciprocating compressor. The document also includes various tables with emission factors and component counts for different equipment and services related to onshore petroleum and natural gas production, gathering, boosting, and transmission compression, as well as underground natural gas storage and LNG storage. These tables provide detailed emission factors for valves, connectors, open-ended lines, pressure relief valves, pumps, and other components, along with the designation of Eastern and Western U.S. states for reference.

truth: Pursuant to a May 2013 final rule, Subpart W BAMM requests are due by June 30 of the year prior to the year in which reports are due (the “reporting year”) and for which BAMM is sought.  As June 30, 2013 falls on a weekend, BAMM requests for the 2014 reporting year are due by July 1, 2013.  The totality of the circumstances related to conducting isolation valve measurement on compressors in shutdown depressurized mode if fully explained in a proper Best Available Monitoring Methods (BAMM) request may be considered by EPA to constitute unique or unusual circumstances justifying the use of BAMM.

It outlines the frequency of measurement, stating that it must be done at least once in any three consecutive calendar years, provided it can be taken during a scheduled shutdown. If there is no scheduled shutdown within three consecutive calendar years, the measurement must be taken at the next scheduled depressurized shutdown. The requirement does not apply if the compressor has blind flanges in place throughout the reporting year. The document also provides methods for performing as found measurements from individual centrifugal and reciprocating compressor sources, and it outlines the general requirements for conducting volumetric emission measurements on each centrifugal and reciprocating compressor. The document also mentions the use of a common vent for routing gas from multiple compressors and the requirement for conducting measurements at the common vent stack. question: In 98.233(e), is the daily thoroughput for glycol dehydrators based on annual average daily thoroughput?
answer: In 98.233(e), the daily throughput for glycol dehydrators is based on whether the annual average daily natural gas throughput is greater than or equal to 0.4 million standard cubic feet per day or less than 0.4 million standard cubic feet per day. The calculation methods for annual mass emissions from glycol dehydrators are specified based on the daily natural gas throughput, and different methods are used for dehydrators with different throughputs. The document also mentions the use of software programs like AspenTech HYSYS® or GRI–GLYCalc TM for calculating emissions, as well as the determination of various parameters by engineering estimate based on best available data. Additionally, it specifies the reporting requirements for dehydrators that use desiccant and the calculation methods for their emissions. The provided tables contain default whole gas emission factors, average component counts, whole gas leaker emission factors, total hydrocarbon emission factors, total hydrocarbon leaker emission factors, total hydrocarbon population emission factors, methane leaker emission factors, methane population emission factors, and methane emission factors for natural gas distribution. These tables provide specific emission factors and counts for different components and services, which can be used in the calculation methods for annual mass emissions from glycol dehydrators.
context:
In 98.233(e), the daily throughput for glycol dehydrators is based on whether the annual average daily natural gas throughput is greater than or equal to 0.4 million standard cubic feet per day or less than 0.4 million standard cubic feet per day. The calculation methods for annual mass emissions from glycol dehydrators are specified based on the daily natural gas throughput, and different methods are used for dehydrators with different throughputs. The document also mentions the use of software programs like AspenTech HYSYS® or GRI–GLYCalc TM for calculating emissions, as well as the determination of various parameters by engineering estimate based on best available data. Additionally, it specifies the reporting requirements for dehydrators that use desiccant and the calculation methods for their emissions.{

truth: The daily throughput of 0.4 million standard cubic feet (MMscf) per day for dehydrators referenced in §98.233(e) is based on annual average daily throughput.
relevance_reason: The answer provides a clear and accurate explanation of the daily throughput for glycol dehydrators in 98.233(e), including the conditions under which it is based on the annual average daily natural gas throughput. The answer also mentions the calculation methods for annual mass emissions from glycol dehydrators, the use of software programs for calculating emissions, and the reporting requirements for dehydrators that use desiccant. Additionally, the answer references the provided tables containing default emission factors and counts for different components and services, which can be used in the calculation methods for annual mass emissions from glycol dehydrators.
groundedness_reason: The answer provides a clear and direct response to the question, stating that the daily throughput for glycol dehydrators in 98.233(e) is based on whether the annual average daily natural gas throughput is greater than or equal to 0.4 million standard cubic feet per day or less than 0.4 million standard cubic feet per day. The answer also provides additional information about the calculation methods for annual mass emissions from glycol dehydrators and the use of software programs and engineering estimates for determining various parameters. The answer is supported by the context provided.
dontknowness_reason: The answer provides a clear and complete explanation of the daily throughput for glycol dehydrators and the calculation methods for annual mass emissions. There is no uncertainty or lack of knowledge conveyed in the answer.
coherence_reason: The answer provides a clear and concise explanation of the daily throughput for glycol dehydrators in 98.233(e), including the conditions under which it is based on the annual average daily natural gas throughput. The answer also mentions the calculation methods for annual mass emissions from glycol dehydrators and the use of software programs and engineering estimates for determining various parameters. Additionally, the answer references the provided tables containing specific emission factors and counts for different components and services, which can be used in the calculation methods for annual mass emissions from glycol dehydrators. The sentences in the answer fit together well and sound natural as a whole.

question: Do dehydrators which are used to dry a liquid stream meet the definition of dehydrator?
answer: The document provides a detailed definition of a dehydrator as a device that uses a liquid absorbent to directly contact a natural gas stream to absorb water vapor. It also mentions specific environmental terms such as dehydrator absorbent circulation rate, closed-loop system, wet natural gas, and dehydrator vents. Additionally, it outlines the requirements for reporting information related to different types of dehydrators based on their natural gas throughput. However, the document does not explicitly mention dehydrators used to dry a liquid stream, so it does not directly address the question about whether such dehydrators meet the definition provided.
truth: No, per §98.6, a "dehydrator is" a device in which "a liquid absorbent (including desiccant, ethylene glycol, diethylene glycol, or triethylene glycol) directly contacts a natural gas stream to absorb water vapor."
relevance_reason: The answer mostly lacks relevance as it talks about the definition of a dehydrator and its specific environmental terms, but does not directly address the question about whether dehydrators used to dry a liquid stream meet the definition provided.
groundedness_reason: The answer explicitly states that the document does not address the question about whether dehydrators used to dry a liquid stream meet the provided definition of a dehydrator. Therefore, it is not possible to determine whether the answer is true or false without further information.

truth: Under §98.232(e), emissions from flare stacks are not required to be reported as a separate emission source for onshore natural gas transmission compression facilities.  However, this does not exclude the reporting of flared emissions from the other emission sources listed in §98.232(e) if they are routed to a flare.  The flare source type in §98.233(n) covers only emissions that are not reported in association with any of the other source types in §98.233; see §98.233(n)(10).  For example, if transmission storage tank emissions are going to a flare, then the rule requires the adjustment of transmission storage tank emissions sent to flare per §98.233(k)(4).  The flared transmission storage tank emissions, however, have to be reported as transmission storage tank emissions under §98.236(c)(9).

truth: 40 CFR § 98.238 defines a flare as “…a combustion device, whether at ground level or elevated, that uses an open or closed flame to combust waste gases without energy recovery.”  An open pipe without combustion would not be considered a flare, but any hydrocarbon releases through it would be considered “vented emissions” under §98.238, which includes “process designed flow to the atmosphere through seals or vent pipes.”
